evidence:
Though approaches to each of the CBL design themes vary from
course to course, in response to section 1: Values and Background, we adopt
four shared values for ethical collaboration across our courses: respect
(acknowledging the aims of different parties and the value of those goals),
beneficence (working for better outcomes while minimizing harms), jus-
tice (seeking equitable and appropriate distributions of resources and
duties), and reflexivity (recognizing the perspectives of different stake-
holders impacted by the partnerships). A set of shared values guiding our
CBL redesigns is fitting, because both courses include ethical commit-
ments as part of the course content: PHIL115 presents theories of value
and right action, and applies them as an assessment framework, and
